newsitem.title: FINLAND: FOCUS - Amer shares fall, sees loss.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Amer shares fall, sees loss.

text.p: Shares in sports goods group Amer-yhtyma Oy fell on Tuesday from last week's peaks after the owner of Wilson and MacGregor golf and tennis equipment warned it would make a clear loss in full-year 1996.
Amer said in a statement it would "remain clearly loss-making" at the pre-tax and extras level, which in 1995 showed a 142 million markka ($31.77 million) profit.
It had earlier said it would be loss-making this year, but not used the qualifier "clearly".
The statement said problems at Amer's Wilson and MacGregor golf operations continue to have a negative impact on the group's results.

Amer's stock, which had risen by some 69 percent in heavy volumes since June to a peak of 120.00 on August 21, fell at one point by five percent but later trimmed losses as brokers reported some foreign demand for the stock.

Amer president Roger Talermo, a former Finnish downhill skiing champion in office since May with a pledge to restructure the company with a focus on sports, said he could "only speculate" about the recent sustained stock gains.

"I think -- and you must allow me to be wrong -- that our clear-cut announcements on the sporting goods focus and a plan to clear up a loss-making unit has probably triggered very positive feedback by institutional investors," he told Reuters.

He said by telephone that investors with a longer-term view -- looking five to 10 years ahead -- may be buying Amer on recovery hopes while those with a one-year scope were sellers on prospects of a near-term loss.
"I honestly think that's what happened," he said. "The long term expectations versus the short-term have caused the volatility."
This also explained the weight of volume in recent trades -- bigger investors would usually move in bigger quantities.
But he said he had not had any direct contact with funds or institutional investors that would underpin this view. "I don't have a clue in that respect," he said.
Asked how he viewed the possibility that the buying may be driven by efforts to trigger a takeover, he said it was "a likelihood theoretically".

But he said he understood the Finnish institutional holders of Amer's vote-controlling K-shares, who held talks earlier this year about possibly selling their holdings, were not now in a hurry to sell.
"I read (that) some of them said, 'let's wait and see,'" he said.
